questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a mass in the left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. During this period, the mass has not increased in size and the patient has had no pain. Three months ago, she hit her left chest against the closet door and it was painful for a day. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm well-defined, rubbery, nontender mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumors may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. This 29-year-old woman lacks the characteristic symptoms of phyllodes tumor, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papillomas most commonly manifest with unilateral bloody nipple discharge and are typically located in the central area of the breast (because ductal tissue is more concentrated there) rather than the upper outer quadrant. Furthermore, they are more common in older patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes of the breast are the most common benign lesions of the breast and typically manifest with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On exam, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A nontender, well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency in a 29-year-old woman with no mastalgia, no changes in the skin over the breast, nor axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Fibroadenomas should be closely monitored with clinical breast examinations and imaging (ultrasound and/or mammogram). Ultrasound-guided biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy if lesions increase in size or have atypical imaging findings (e.g., calcifications).

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient has none of the findings of Paget disease of the breast, such as nipple and areola erythema, scaly rash, pruritus, nipple discharge, or retraction, it is an unlikely diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma is usually associated with suspicious characteristics, including: age > 35 years, positive family history, skin changes, axillary adenopathy, asymmetry, and a firm, rigid mass with irregular borders. None of these features are present in this patient, meaning that carcinoma is unlikely. Nevertheless, this patient should undergo mammography to rule out any potential suspicious radiological signs.

G) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is characterized by skin changes, specifically breast erythema, dimpling, and diffuse swelling that is similar in appearance to the peel of an orange (often termed “peau d'orange”). These symptoms are not present in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Although patients with fat necrosis of the breast commonly report a history of breast trauma, this condition typically manifests as a firm, periareolar mass with irregular borders that may have an overlying area of skin thickening or retraction. This patient's well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency makes a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast is likely to show a well-defined mass with homogeneous hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman at 17-weeks gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless mass in the right breast for the last 3 weeks that has not increased in size. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm rubbery, mobile mass that is nontender in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. A biopsy of the mass shows rounded contour with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presence of a solid, painless, mobile mass in a 33-year-old pregnant woman without any mastalgia, changes in skin over the breast, or axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma, the most common breast tumor (although benign) in women < 35 years of age. This pregnant patient's elevated estrogen levels have likely contributed to the mass appearance. A biopsy showing overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue confirms the diagnosis.

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

An intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of unilateral bloody nipple discharge (not present in this patient). It is also associated with older patients and is typically located in the central area of the breast (because ductal tissue is more concentrated there) and not in the upper outer quadrant, making it an unlikely diagnosis. Biopsy varies shows fibrovascular tissues surrounded by epithelial cells within lactiferous ducts.

C) INCORRECT:

Breasts increase in size and may be tender during pregnancy, but masses are not normal and should be evaluated further. However, hormone-responsive masses can increase in size during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic change of the breast is the most common benign lesion of the breast and typically presents with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On examination, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis. Biopsy findings vary and include stromal fibrosis, cysts, papillary apocrine changes, and mild epithelial hyperplasia or calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis presents as an area of ecchymosis, erythema, and/or skin thickening following trauma to the breast, none of which are present in this patient. Biopsy would show fat necrosis with foam cells, multinucleated giant cells, hemosiderin deposition, and/or chronic inflammation.

F) INCORRECT:

Unlike in this patient, phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), grow at a fast rate, and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumor may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. A biopsy would show leaf-like architecture with papillary projection of epithelium-lined stroma.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast would likely show a well-defined mass with generally uniform hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a follow-up examination 6 weeks after presenting with a painless mass in her left breast. Breast and pubic hair development began at the age of 10 years. Menarche started at the age of 13 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 5 days ago. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears well and is at the 65th percentile for both height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 3. Palpation of the left breast shows a nontender, rubbery, discrete, and mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant. There are no overlying skin changes or associated warmth and no nipple retraction or discharge; these findings are unchanged since the last visit. Examination of the right breast and axillary lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the left breast shows a well-circumscribed, solid 1.5 x 1.1-cm mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up examination in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most common palpable breast mass in patients < 35 years of age is fibroadenoma, a benign breast tumor that has a good prognosis and often resolves spontaneously. A biopsy would confirm the diagnosis but can be avoided in adolescent patients who have ultrasound findings consistent with fibroadenoma (i.e., a solid mass with well-defined borders) and low clinical suspicion of malignancy (e.g., no systemic symptoms, no red flags for breast cancer, such as nipple discharge and skin retraction). Adolescent patients with a breast mass consistent with fibroadenoma are typically managed with follow-up examinations every 6–12 months for 1–2 years. Follow-up is necessary to evaluate for tumor growth, which would warrant further investigation and potentially surgical excision to exclude rare differential diagnoses (e.g., phyllodes tumor, malignancy).
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the evaluation of palpable breast masses in individuals ≥ 40 years of age. This modality is also recommended for breast cancer screening because it can detect the majority of malignancies and lesions ∼ 2 years before they are clinically evident as palpable masses. However, mammography is less sensitive in younger patients who have greater breast density due to high amounts of glandular tissue and is typically not used in individuals < 30 years of age. Finally, this patient's ultrasound and examination findings are consistent with fibroadenoma, for which further imaging is likely not necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) can be used to evaluate cystic breast lesions. If clear nonbloody fluid is aspirated and the lesion resolves, a simple cyst is the most likely diagnosis. Other fluids (e.g., bloody discharge) require further cytological evaluation. This patient's ultrasound findings show a solid mass, for which FNA is not the best diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient most likely has a fibroadenoma, a benign tumor that often resolves spontaneously, reassurance alone is not sufficient. Follow-up is necessary to evaluate for tumor growth, which would warrant further investigation to exclude rare differential diagnoses (e.g., phyllodes tumor, malignancy).

E) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy is only indicated in adolescent patients with a palpable breast mass that is > 5 cm in diameter and/or growing larger. Excision may also be indicated for suspected breast lesions (firm, nontender masses, with poorly-defined margins) and/or for masses that cause excessive worry for the patient or caregivers. This patient likely has a small fibroadenoma (< 2 cm in diameter), which requires a different step in management.
questions.hint: In an otherwise healthy adolescent, a nontender breast mass that remains unchanged for 6 weeks and is solid with well-defined borders on ultrasound suggests fibroadenoma.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with a painless, firm breast lump noticed two months ago. She is otherwise healthy and reports no significant family history of breast disease. Physical examination reveals a 2-cm, well-demarcated, mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast, with no skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy (see report).
Ultrasound: Solid lesion with smooth margins
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma, common in older women, presents with irregular, spiculated margins on imaging. The patient's young age, well-demarcated and mobile mass, and ultrasound findings of a solid lesion with smooth margins argue against malignancy. Malignant lesions often show irregular features and may have regional lymphadenopathy, which are absent here.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes involve diffuse, often bilateral nodularity and cyst formation, typically presenting with cyclic breast pain. The 2-cm, firm, mobile, and painless lump with smooth margins on ultrasound suggests a localized lesion, unlike the diffuse pattern of fibrocystic changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors, part of the fibroepithelial spectrum, usually occur in slightly older women and present as rapidly enlarging masses, often larger than 2 cm. The patient's age, the small size of the mass, and ultrasound findings of a solid lesion with smooth margins suggest a benign process, making a phyllodes tumor less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Fibroadenomas are common benign breast tumors in young women, presenting as painless, firm, well-demarcated, and mobile masses. The patient's age and the mass's characteristics align with a fibroadenoma, often called a 'breast mouse' due to its mobility. Ultrasound shows a solid lesion with smooth margins, typical of fibroadenomas. The absence of skin changes and axillary lymphadenopathy further supports a benign diagnosis. Hormonal factors influence fibroadenoma growth, explaining their prevalence in reproductive-aged women.

Key learning point: Fibroadenomas are common benign breast tumors in young women, presenting as smooth, mobile, and well-circumscribed masses.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to your clinic for evaluation of a mass in her left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. The mass has not changed in size and she has not experienced any pain. She recalls hitting her left chest against a closet door 3 months ago, which caused pain for one day. Her menstrual cycles are regular every 28 days, lasting 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. On examination, her breasts are dense and there is a 2.5-cm, well-defined, rubbery, nontender, mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although patients with fat necrosis of the breast commonly report a history of breast trauma, this condition typically manifests as a firm, periareolar mass with irregular borders that may have an overlying area of skin thickening or retraction. This patient's well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) CORRECT:

A nontender, well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency in a 29-year-old woman with no mastalgia, no changes in the skin over the breast, nor axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Fibroadenomas should be closely monitored with clinical breast examinations and imaging (ultrasound and/or mammogram). Ultrasound-guided biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy if lesions increase in size or have atypical imaging findings (e.g., calcifications).

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.

Key learning point: A well-circumscribed, mobile, rubbery, nontender breast mass in a woman under 35 is most likely a fibroadenoma, the most common benign breast tumor in young women.

C) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumors may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. This 29-year-old woman lacks the characteristic symptoms of phyllodes tumor, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes of the breast are the most common benign lesions of the breast and typically manifest with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On exam, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma is usually associated with suspicious characteristics, including: age > 35 years, positive family history, skin changes, axillary adenopathy, asymmetry, and a firm, rigid mass with irregular borders. None of these features are present in this patient, meaning that carcinoma is unlikely. Nevertheless, this patient should undergo mammography to rule out any potential suspicious radiological signs.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast is likely to show a well-defined mass with homogeneous hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a breast lump she found during a self-exam. She denies pain, nipple discharge, or skin changes. Her menstrual cycles are regular. On examination, a 2-cm, firm, non-tender, well-demarcated mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most characteristic of this lesion?

choices.text: High degree of mobility on palpation
Fixation of the mass to the chest wall
Fluctuance of the mass on palpation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of a firm, non-tender, and well-demarcated breast mass in a woman under 35 years of age is highly suggestive of a fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are benign, encapsulated tumors composed of stromal and epithelial tissue. Their most classic physical examination finding is being highly mobile and easily movable within the breast tissue, often described as a 'breast mouse' because it seems to slip away from the examining fingers. These tumors are also typically rubbery in consistency. As they are estrogen-sensitive, they may increase in size during pregnancy or with oral contraceptive use. The initial diagnostic step is typically a breast ultrasound, followed by a core needle biopsy if confirmation is needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Fixation of a breast mass to the underlying chest wall or deep fascia suggests local invasion by a malignant tumor, which is not consistent with the well-demarcated and likely benign nature of the lesion described in this young patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Nipple discharge can be associated with various breast conditions. Spontaneous, unilateral, and particularly bloody or serosanguinous discharge is concerning for an intraductal papilloma or malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluctuance on palpation indicates a fluid-filled structure, such as a simple breast cyst or a breast abscess. The mass in this patient is described as firm, which suggests a solid, rather than cystic, lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Skin dimpling, or peau d'orange, is a sign of an underlying malignancy. It occurs when a tumor invades and shortens the suspensory ligaments of the breast (Cooper's ligaments), pulling the skin inward. This is not a characteristic feature of the benign lesion suggested by the patient's presentation.
questions.hint: This patient's age and the description of a firm, well-demarcated, non-tender mass are consistent with the most common benign breast tumor in young women.

questions.text:
EoR checklist:-Name added as author responsible? Y-Stem is clinically plausible? Y-Lead-in and options match the LO and tested competency? Y- Highlighting checked? Y- AT checked? Y- Key is correct? Y- Explanation of the key checked? Y- Important style checked? Y- Linked AA and section checked? Y-Single best answer? Y-If not, removing 1 answer option solves the issue? N/A- Incorrect options and explanations checked? Y- Question has major inconsistencies with AA content? N- Main subject added? Y
A 22-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a left breast lump she discovered on self-examination one month ago. She describes the lump as painless and reports no associated nipple discharge or skin changes. The size has not varied with her menstrual cycle. Her paternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 65. On examination, a 2-cm, firm, non-tender, well-circumscribed mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The mass is freely movable within the breast tissue. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that presents as a soft, well-circumscribed, and mobile mass. This condition is plausible in a woman with a palpable breast mass, but it is almost exclusively seen in women who are currently pregnant, lactating, or have recently stopped breastfeeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes can cause firm breast lumps, but they are typically characterized by multiple, often bilateral, nodular or rope-like areas that are painful or tender. A key feature is that symptoms, including lump size and tenderness, classically fluctuate with the menstrual cycle, worsening in the premenstrual phase. This patient has a solitary, painless mass that remains unchanged throughout her menstrual cycle.

C) CORRECT:

A fibroadenoma is the most common benign breast tumor in women under 30. It typically presents as a solitary, firm, non-tender, and highly mobile mass. These tumors are composed of stromal and epithelial tissue and are hormonally responsive, though they typically do not fluctuate in size with the menstrual cycle. The well-circumscribed nature and lack of associated skin changes or lymphadenopathy are also characteristic. While family history is noted, the patient's young age and the specific physical exam findings strongly favor this benign diagnosis. Initial evaluation typically involves a breast ultrasound to confirm the solid nature of the mass.

D) INCORRECT:

A simple breast cyst presents as a smooth, well-circumscribed, and often tender mass. While it can be firm if tense with fluid, its size and tenderness commonly fluctuate with the menstrual cycle. This patient's mass is firm, non-tender, and has been stable in size for a month, making a simple cyst less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors are rare fibroepithelial tumors that can feel similar to fibroadenomas on palpation. However, they are characterized by rapid growth and typically occur in an older age group, with a peak incidence in women in their 40s. This patient's young age and the mass's stable size over one month make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: The high mobility of this breast mass, often described as a 'breast mouse,' is a classic feature of the most common benign breast tumor in this age group.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a right breast lump she discovered one month ago. She does not have pain, nipple discharge, or skin changes. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she has no family history of breast cancer. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm, firm, rubbery, and highly mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. A breast ultrasound shows a well-circumscribed, hypoechoic solid mass, corresponding to a BI-RADS 3 lesion. A subsequent ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy confirms the diagnosis of fibroadenoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a diagnostic mammogram of the right breast
Reassurance with return for annual clinical examination
Refer for breast MRI for further characterization
Proceed with excisional biopsy of the mass
Repeat clinical examination and ultrasound in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A diagnostic mammogram is a tool used to evaluate breast abnormalities. However, it has lower sensitivity in young women under 30 due to dense breast tissue, making ultrasound the preferred modality. More importantly, a definitive histologic diagnosis has already been made via biopsy, rendering further diagnostic imaging unnecessary at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

While reassurance is an important component of managing a benign finding, returning to routine annual screening is not sufficient for initial follow-up.

C) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is a highly sensitive imaging modality, but it is not indicated for routine evaluation of a mass that has been definitively diagnosed as a benign fibroadenoma by core needle biopsy. Its use is typically reserved for high-risk screening or for complex cases where other imaging modalities are inconclusive.

D) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy provides both diagnosis and treatment for a breast mass. However, in this case, a definitive diagnosis of a benign fibroadenoma has already been established via a less invasive core needle biopsy. Since the mass is small and asymptomatic, proceeding to surgery would be considered overtreatment.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a biopsy-confirmed fibroadenoma, a common benign breast tumor composed of stromal and epithelial elements. Given her age, the asymptomatic nature of the 1.5-cm mass, and the definitive benign diagnosis, conservative management with surveillance is the most appropriate approach. A follow-up clinical breast exam and ultrasound in 6 months is the standard of care to monitor for stability or growth. This avoids the morbidity of unnecessary surgery. Surgical excision is typically reserved for fibroadenomas that are large (e.g., >2 cm), rapidly growing, symptomatic, or if the patient has a strong preference for removal.
